title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Lawyers on Monday laid out their cases on day one of the trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, who is charged with killing George Floyd.

Prosecutor Jerry Blackwell said Chauvin betrayed his badge when he used excessive force to subdue Floyd on May 25 last year, which was captured on video by a bystander and posted online. The video will be a crucial part of the prosecution case.

“You can believe your eyes,” he said. “It's homicide. It's murder.”

But the defence for the former police officer zoomed out on a sweeping investigation with almost 50,000 pieces of evidence, raising questions about the cause of Floyd's death and what constituted reasonable use of force.

“Derek Chauvin did exactly what he had been trained to do over his 19-year career. The use of force is not attractive, but it is a necessary component of policing,” said defence attorney Eric Nelson.

Both attorneys underlined that, despite intense public interest, Chauvin's trial was separate from larger social questions about racism and accountability in US policing.

Chauvin is charged with second- and third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter. He has pleaded not guilty. The case continues. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • A key measure of US long-term borrowing costs has hit its highest level since the early days of the coronavirus crisis as traders sold Treasuries at the end of a brutal quarter for global government bonds.

  • Joe Biden is racing to expand vaccination eligibility, after a senior US health official said she felt a sense of “impending doom” about surging infections.

  • Canada has suspended the use of the Oxford/AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine for younger adults as a “precautionary measure” following concerns in Europe.

  • GlaxoSmithKline will help manufacture up to 60m doses of Novavax's vaccine to boost supplies in the UK, where it is still awaiting approval.

  • Boris Johnson hailed Monday's easing of England's lockdown as “a small step to freedom”. London reported zero Covid-19 deaths on Sunday for the second time this year but the capital's vaccine rollout lags behind the rest of the country.

  • Severe debt in the wake of the pandemic threatens to tip developing countries into a crisis, António Guterres, UN secretary-general, told the Financial Times. (FT, Evening Standard)

Comparing the EU and US relief packages diminishes historic efforts taken to boost economies, writes Paschal Donohoe, eurogroup president and Ireland's finance minister. Follow our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email.

In the news

Exclusive: US to encourage diplomats to meet Taiwan officials The Biden administration is preparing to make it easier for US diplomats to meet Taiwanese officials, adopting changes introduced by Donald Trump, in a move China is likely to see as a provocation. (FT)

Archegos banks discussed co-operation to head off selling frenzy Before the troubles at Archegos Capital Management burst into public view, representatives from its trading partners — Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse, UBS and Nomura — held a meeting to discuss an orderly wind-down of troubled trades. The talks failed, paving the way for days of chaotic trading. (FT)

David Cameron faces Greensill probe The former UK prime minister is facing an investigation by an influential standards watchdog over his links to Lex Greensill, whose eponymous supply chain financing company collapsed this month. The Australian financier would often boast of a desert trip with Cameron and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

Suez Canal ship freed The skyscraper-sized container ship that had been stuck in the Suez Canal for almost a week was finally freed on Monday, reopening one of the world's main trade arteries. Total insurance claims from the blockage are expected to run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Russia has seized on the incident to tout its alternative Arctic sea route to Asia. For Egyptians, the canal is not only a foreign currency earner, but also a symbol of sovereignty. (FT)

Erdogan fires central bank deputy governor Turkey's president Recep Tayyip Erdogan has sacked Murat Cetinkaya, the central bank's deputy governor, 10 days after he dismissed its head and sparked a sharp sell-off in financial markets on fears of a return to unorthodox monetary policy. (FT)

The day ahead

WHO Covid origins report A World Health Organization investigation into the origins of the pandemic is due to be released on Tuesday. A version of the report seen by the FT concluded that Covid-19 was “extremely unlikely” to have been the result of a laboratory leak. (FT)

Earnings Lululemon Athletica, which has grown rapidly in the past year on the back of higher demand from housebound consumers for athleisurewear, reports earnings today. (FT)

Economic data Chile's central bank has a rate decision due. IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva delivers a speech ahead of its spring meeting. Consumer confidence data for the US is also out. (FT, IMF)

Human rights Antony Blinken, secretary of state, will unveil the State department's annual human rights report today, which documents the status of human rights and worker rights in nearly 200 countries and territories, and is likely to shine a spotlight on China and Myanmar. (US embassy)

What else we're reading

A second cold war is tracking the first In Washington, Beijing and Moscow, officials all say that they want to avoid a new cold war. But Gideon Rachman warns that as a US-led western alliance again squares up against Russia and China, the parallels with the early years of the cold war look increasingly convincing, even eerie. (FT)

The echoes of Enron in Greensill saga It is 20 years since Enron collapsed. Yet the nature of the energy giant's boom and bust has some striking echoes in the rise and fall of Lex Greensill, writes Patrick Jenkins. It is still unclear whether any fraud took place in Greensill's case. But aggressive innovation certainly did. (FT)

American but still ‘Asian enough' to be attacked Since the killings at Asian spas and massage parlours in Georgia this month, many adopted Asian Americans have begun expressing, and sometimes admitting to themselves for the first time, the angst of being people of colour raised by white people, writes Patti Waldmeir, a white parent of an adopted Chinese-American daughter. (FT)

Mozambique conflict flares Dozens of people have been killed in an attack on Palma, a town in north-east Mozambique at the centre of an Islamist uprising. It is also home to one of Africa's largest energy projects. How dangerous is the situation — and what does this mean for gas investments? Sign up for our Energy Source newsletter, every Tuesday and Thursday. (FT)

The search for alien life beyond Mars If extraterrestrial life does exist beyond Earth, scientists may find traces of it soon. The expanding quest for clues is gaining respectability, with Nasa preparing to launch a $4.25bn mission to Europa, around Jupiter, in 2024 to study whether the moon's frozen environments could accommodate alien biology. (WSJ)

Video of the day

‘Pandemics are no longer natural disasters, they're political failures' Historian and philosopher Yuval Noah Harari talks to Alec Russell, the FT Weekend editor, about nationalism versus global leadership — and the perils of a perpetual surveillance state. One of the highlights of the FT Weekend Spring Festival 2021. (FT)
